awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: ABI Development: The next stage in protein-protein docking
awd_abstract_narration:
Protein-protein interactions are integral to many mechanisms of cellular control, including protein localization, allosteric and gene regulation and signal transduction, and therefore their characterization is an important task for both experimental and computational approaches to systems biology. Genome-wide proteomics studies provide a growing list of putative protein-protein interactions, and demonstrate that most if not all proteins have interacting partners in the cell. However, these techniques can only identify whether two proteins possibly interact. A full comprehension of how proteins bind and form complexes can only come from high-resolution three-dimensional structures, since they provide the atomic details necessary to understand how the interactions occur and how the high degree of specificity can be achieved.  While the most complete structural characterization is provided by X-ray crystallography, many biologically important interactions occur in weak, transient complexes that are not amenable to direct experimental analysis, even when both proteins can be isolated and their structures determined. The goal of this project is to further improve the protein-protein docking server ClusPro that, starting from the structures of component proteins, attempts to determine the structure of their complexes with accuracy close to that provided by X-ray crystallography. The server at https://cluspro.org  already has close to 10,000 registered users, although it can also be used without registration. Docked structures generated by ClusPro have been reported in over 600 research papers. The public server is important for biological and chemical scientists who may not have extensive computational experience but still will be able to use state of the art docking methods. The increased availability of protein complex structures will have major impact in many areas of biology, biochemistry, and biotechnology. 

The project has six aims focusing on problems of increasing difficulty. First, a new opportunity to progress is provided by earlier development of the manifold fast Fourier transform (FFT) correlation algorithm, which increased the speed of sampling by orders of magnitude. An additional advantage of the method is that increasing the number of correlation function terms is computationally inexpensive. Therefore, Aim 1 is the development and implementation of complex energy functions, including distance-dependent and three-body potentials for scoring. Second, recently developed methods have shown considerable promise in predicting contacts between residues in proteins using evolutionary covariance information. The problem is that these methods require large numbers of evolutionarily related sequences of interacting proteins to robustly assess the extent of residue covariation. Aim 2 is exploring how sequence information can be used for extracting inter-protein contacts to improve docking results even with somewhat limited number of sequences. Third, with the increase in the number of protein complex structures, there is increasing need for integrating direct docking and template-based prediction methods, and several strategies will be explored to implement such integration. Fourth, the docking method will be modified to work optimally with homology models rather than X-ray structures of interacting proteins. The fifth aim is exploring new approaches to the docking of proteins with substantial backbone conformational changes upon binding. The sixth and final aim is implementing the newly developed algorithms in the ClusPro server.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Protein-protein interactions play a central role in various aspects of the structural and functional organization of the cell, and their elucidation is crucial for a better understanding of processes such as metabolic control, signal transduction, and gene regulation. However, at present detailed experimental structure is available only a small fraction of complexes. Thus, it is important to develop computational methods that can elucidate the details of specific interactions. The major goal of this proposal was to further improve our public server, ClusPro, for predicting the three-dimensional structures of protein-protein complexes. According to the ongoing worldwide experiment CAPRI (Critical Assessment of Predicted Interactions), ClusPro consistently has been among the best protein-protein docking servers and has a large user base.

We have explored several unsolved problems to improve the performance of the method. First, we added the option of using a template-based approach, and explored optimal template selection and the best combination of template-based and traditional docking. Machine learning based methods were  developed both for improved ranking of clusters of models generated by ClusPro and for predicting the conformations of interface side chains. We also investigated the performance and its limits of the rigid body docking used by ClusPro. In particular, we focused on antibody-antigen docking and developed the companion server, ClusPro AbEMap, for predicting antibody epitopes based on structure of an antigen and either the structure or only the sequence of an antibody. We also explored how well modeled proteins conserve the binding properties of the original X-ray structures, and served as the official evaluators of the functional properties of predicted structures in Round 14 of the CASP (Critical Assessment of Structure Prediction) experiment in 2020. The results of CASP14 revealed the outstanding performance of neural net based method called AlphaFold2 for protein structure prediction. AlphaFold2 (AF2) and Aphafold-Multimer (AFM), released in 2021, also provide excellent docking results for many proteins, but the success rates are much lower for antigen-antibody and protein-peptides complexes. We have shown that performance in these applications can be substantially improved by combining AF2 and AFM with ClusPro, and we have started to implement this protocol in a new server. We also explored the application of protein docking to predicting the structure of ternary complexes for the design of PROTACs (PROteolysis TArgeting Chimeras) that represent an emerging therapeutic technology. The design requires bringing an E3 ligase protein into proximity with a protein target using a bifunctional PROTAC molecule, and thereby modulating the concentration of the target through its ubiquitination and degradation. The prediction problem was solved by developing an extended version of the docking algorithm used in ClusPro. The method generates both favorable poses of the two proteins and acceptable conformations of the flexible linker in the PROTAC by a single and very efficient computational step.

ClusPro currently has over 26,000 registered users and performs about 15,000 docking calculations per month. Structures generated by the server have been reported in over 2500 research papers. The models are frequently validated by experimental techniques, including site-directed mutagenesis or cross-linking. Because these techniques are relatively inexpensive, docking helps to obtain detailed biological and biomedical information at much reduced costs. The results can be used in engineering proteins for particular applications, e.g., for biopharmaceutics or protein based biomaterials, and also help in selecting protein-protein interactions that can be targeted by drug discovery. Research and software development was  performed by graduate and undergraduate students. Students participating in the research acquired experience to meet both computational and experimental challenges, with particular emphasis on the use of machine learning algorithms for protein modeling and docking. During the three years of the project six Ph.D. students, including four females, graduated from the PIs lab, and all moved to excellent positions in pharmaceutical or biotechnology companies. The program used in the ClusPro server has been licensed both to a faculty startup and to Schr?dinger Inc., which incorporated it as part  of Bioluminate, a software package for modeling and design of biologics.

 


Last Modified: 11/12/2022
Modified by: Sandor Vajda
